Mike,

I believe the situation you identify only comes up because you 
happ=
ened to choose two species that both have the same number of 
members, whic=
h causes both to be divided by the same number, making 
the "sharing" (whic=
h is represented by the division) moot.

If you try situations where specie=
s have different sizes you should 
discover quite different results.

ken

=

fitness

pulation with 100 members.

nesses of (say)

ted fitnesses are just the

justed fitness for that species of 
20?
> 
>

also with 5 members but unadjusted
> fitnesses of twice
> the above
> 40,28=
,32,40,60  , with a total adjusted fitness for that species 
of 40

Allocating offspring by adjusted fitness would give 2 times more 
to B
> th=
an A which makes sense, except the same could be achieved by just

the unadjusted fitness levels without needing to average

 which is where I'm confused.

ch has some info on this,

just summing the unadjsuted

A has 100 , so B still
